content:
Here are my advances related to research during my PhD: Statistical software  [Retrieving data] Using the packages quandland BIS,I’ve learned techniques to retrieve data online. The first is used to collect financial markets data, while the second offers a direct connection to the data supplied by the Bank for International Settlements.Example of code with quandl:
library(quantmod)library(dplyr)# DATA FROM YAHOO FINANCE# IBOVESPA (^BVSP)getSymbols("^BVSP",src="yahoo", from="1900-01-01")BVSP.DF <- data.frame(Date=index(BVSP),coredata(BVSP))BVSP.DF <- dplyr::select(BVSP.DF,Date, BVSP.Close)plot(BVSP.DF) Example of code with BIS:
library(devtools)library(BIS)library(dplyr)library(ggplot2)# DATA FROM BIS# POLICY RATES (INTEREST RATES)datasets <- get_datasets()head(datasets, 23)prates <- get_bis(datasets$url[23], quiet = TRUE)BRLIR <- subset(prates, ref_area == "BR")BRLIR <- dplyr::select(BRLIR, date, obs_value)names(BRLIR)[names(BRLIR) == "obs_value"] <- "BRLIR"BRLIR <- BRLIR[BRLIR$date >= "2000-01-01" & BRLIR$date <= "2020-02-03",]BIR <- ggplot(BRLIR, aes(x=date, y=BRLIR)) +geom_line() + xlab("")BIR [Time series econometrics] I’ve studied the following topics:
 Panel data Vector-autogressive models (VAR) Structural Vector-autogressive models (SVAR) Granger-causality Unit-roots testing   [Programming] I’ve learned to code .do files, like this (Stata 13):
clear alllog using "resultats_`c(current_date)'.log", replacecapture logset more offglobal data "C:\Data\"cd "$data\"import excel "C:\Data\CHF.data.xlsx", firstrowformat Obs %twtsset Obs*** Generate new variablesg CT = Short/Longmvencode CT, mv(0)g IRD = IR - USIR*** Generate variables in first differencesgen dER = d.ER*** Generate variables in logg lER = log(ER)*** Data manipulationdrop if Obs==1*** Group of variablesglobal levelvar ER CT IRD VIX SM SMUSglobal logvar lER lCT IRD lVIX lSM lSMUS*** Graphicsforeach var of varlist $levelvar {quietly: line `var' Obs, saving(level`var', replace)quietly: graph export "`var'-level.pdf", replace}quietly: gr combine levelER.gph levelCT.gph levelIRD.gph levelVIX.gph levelSM.gph levelSMUS.gph, saving(level_all, replace)quietly: graph export "level_all.pdf", replace*** Generate time dummy, following changes in IR (Switzerland, SNB)*** PI dummy is equal to one in the period of positive interest ratesgen PI=(Obs<=378)*** NI dummy is equal to one in the period of negative interest rates (23 December *> 2014, onwards).gen NI=(Obs>=379)*** QE2 dummy is equal to one to the recent QE in the U.S.gen QE2=(Obs>=620)*** Unit root testsclemao1 ERputexcel B2=rscalars using results, sheet("CLEMAO") modifyclemao1 CTputexcel C2=rscalars using results, sheet("CLEMAO") modify*** Correlation matrixpwcorr $logvar, sig*** Histogram graphsforeach var of varlist $logvar {quietly: histogram `var', freq normal saving(`var', replace)quietly: graph export "l`var'.pdf", replace}*** Combine graphsquietly: gr combine lCT.gph lER.gph IRD.gph lVIX.gph lSM.gph lSMUS.gph, saving(histogram_log_all, replace)quietly: graph export "histogram_log_all.pdf", replace*** Closing logsave Granger.dta, replacesaveold Granger_stata13.dta, replacesave "$data\Granger.dta", replacelog close [Time series econometrics] As with R, I’ve also studied the following topics:
 Panel data Vector-autogressive models (VAR) Structural Vector-autogressive models (SVAR) Granger-causality Unit-roots testing  Publishing Toolkit  Rstudiois an essential tool for me as a researcher. It’s an integrated development environment (IDE) for R. With RStudio, it’s easy to manipulate R. I’ve used all the following tools from RStudio, as well as all the statistical in the first section.  Additionally, rmarkdownis as important as RStudio. It’s an R package used for authoring documents.  To build this site, I’ve used the Academic themefor Hugo.  With xaringan, I’ve created slideshows for presentations.  I’ve used the packages bookdownand rticlesto write academic articles.

summary: Recently, the Swiss National Bank (SNB) has surprised the world of central banking by anchoring the Swiss franc to the euro and setting negative policy rates. This article aims to investigate the interactions of the Swiss carry trade and the related financial variables in both periods of positive and negative policy rates in Switzerland. Using a structural vector autoregressive model (SVAR), we study the behaviour of the carry trade based on five financial variables: nominal exchange rates (USD/CHF), interest rate differentials between Switzerland and the US, market sentiment in the US, Swiss stock market index, and US stock market index. We attained evidence that the Swiss franc acted as a target currency during the period of positive policy rates in Switzerland. With negative interest rates, there is a reinforcement of the CHF as a funding currency. We reach the conclusion that, as long as instability in the International Monetary System prevails, the Swiss franc will continue to play the role of safe haven currency. This role is not problematic only for Switzerland but also for other countries, due to systemic risks posed by the intertwinement of financial markets. The SNB would benefit from strengthening its macro-prudential supervision by establishing new instruments capable of forecasting the impact of trends in financial variables on its monetary policies.
title: Carry trade and negative interest rates in Switzerland
